Tel.: +82 2 3290 3299; fax: +82 2 926 6102. Graphical abstract In this study, we investigated the catalysis of Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 for the synthesis of methanol from CO/CO2/H2 gas. The Ce1−x Zr x O2 was synthesized by a surfactant (CTAB)-assisted co-precipitation method to yield high surface area supports, and Cu was deposited on the supports by a deposition–precipitation method to promote high Cu dispersion. The incorporation of Zr into the CeO2 lattice transformed the structure into a defective, pseudo-cubic one and the amount of incorporated Zr (x) determined the concentration of oxygen vacancy in the lattice. It was proposed that the oxygen vacancy in Ce1−x Zr x O2 played an important role in the catalysis by determining concentration and mobility of the adsorbed CO x on the catalyst. The activity was also influenced by the exposed surface area of Cu and surface acidity of the catalyst, both of which were closely related to the amount of Zr in the support. To reveal the influences of the catalyst properties on methanol production, various characterization techniques were used, such as XPS, Raman spectroscopy, XRD, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, BET and N2O titration methods. Keywords Methanol synthesis Synthesis gas Ce x Zr1−x O2 Cu surface area Oxygen vacancy 1 Introduction Because the applications of methanol have been widely expanded, methanol has recently become one of the most important chemical resources in the world [1]. Methanol is used as the industrial feedstock for the production of formaldehyde, acetic acid and so on. These derivatives are then subsequently used for the manufacture of final products that we use in daily life. Methanol also can be used as an alternative fuel, which might substitute for a portion of conventional fuel, such as gasoline or diesel. Additionally, methanol has been highlighted as a promising feedstock for hydrogen energy when considering the advantages in production, storage and transportation in terms of infrastructural and operational costs [2]. Industrial production of methanol from synthesis gas was first developed by the BASF Company in the 1920s with ZnO/Cr2O3 based catalysts [3]. The process required high pressure (250–350atm) and temperature (623–723K) conditions to which Cu based-catalysts could not be applied because of their poor thermal stability of Cu. At 1960s, the ICI Company introduced a new process that could be operated at relatively low pressure (50–120atm) and temperature (503–573K) with Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts. Since then, extensive studies have been carried out on the Cu-based catalysts for methanol synthesis. The elemental compositions, exposed Cu surface area and reaction conditions have been known to be the major factors that determine the activities of Cu-based catalysts [4–6]. Some topics, such as the nature of the active site, however, are still controversial. Several researchers have insisted that Cu0 is an active site for methanol synthesis because the catalytic activities were proportional to the metallic Cu surface area [5,7,8]. However, certain studies have also claimed that the yield of methanol was affected by the amount of Cu1+ as well as Cu0 [9–12]. These studies proposed that the active phase of Cu was stabilized to Cu1+, which promoted the adsorption of reactants and formation of methanol. According to Sheffer et al., addition of alkali metals enhanced the catalytic activity of Cu because the added alkali ions prevented the reduction of Cu1+ to Cu0 [13]. In addition to active Cu species (Cu0, Cu1+), it has been suggested by many researchers that the oxygen vacancies in the metal oxide support play an important role in the catalysis. Silver et al. and Jackson et al. investigated the relationship between oxygen vacancy of ZrO2 and catalytic activity (methanol productivity) [14,15]. In these studies, CO was adsorbed and activated at the oxygen vacancies of ZrO2. Recently, Grabowski et al. insisted that the oxygen vacancies of ZrO2 stabilized the tetragonal structure, which led to enhanced methanol productivity [16]. The influences of oxygen vacancies have been broadly observed on the activities of catalysts in a variety of CO/CO2-related reactions. The oxygen vacancy of the support material played an important role in reactions such as CO oxidation and CO2 reforming. Li et al. reported that, CO adsorbed on the oxygen vacancy of CeO2 and turned into formate species if the CeO2 was pre-treated with hydrogen [17]. For CO2 reforming, Huang et al. insisted that CO2 was bound to the oxygen vacancy of Gd2O3- or Sm2O3-doped CeO2 and reduced to CO, and subsequently, the detached oxygen from CO2 replaced the other (neighboring) oxygen vacancies in the CeO2 lattice [18]. Dow et al. suggested that the CO was actively adsorbed on the interface between the Cu metal and the oxygen vacancy of ZrO2 in the CO oxidation reaction over Cu-supported Y2O3–ZrO2 [19]. Considering the studies listed so far, it was expected that the oxygen vacancies of CeO2 or ZrO2 could provide effective active sites for CO and CO2 adsorption during methanol synthesis. Numerous studies have reported that CeO2 has a high oxygen storage capacity (OSC) and excellent redox properties [20–23]. However, these properties rapidly disappeared at high temperatures due to its poor thermal stability. To overcome this drawback of CeO2, the incorporation of transition metal oxides into CeO2 has been extensively investigated. Of several mixed oxides, Ce1−x Zr x O2 support has been extensively studied because the addition of Zr into CeO2 improves the redox properties as well as the thermal stability [24,25]. Additionally, the introduction of Zr caused more structural defects (i.e., oxygen vacancies), which facilitated the mobility of lattice oxygen [26]. Ce1−x Zr x O2 catalysts have been applied to oxidation of VOC [26] and CO [27], for which it was reported to have good catalytic activities. However, little is known about the activity of (Cu-supported) Ce1−x Zr x O2 catalysts in methanol synthesis. In this study, we investigated how the amount of Zr (x) in Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 catalysts affected the concentration of oxygen vacancies and the methanol synthesis activities. Using XRD, Raman, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, and XPS analysis, the chemical and physical properties of the prepared catalysts were characterized and correlated with the reaction results. In the activity tests, we used a synthesis gas that contained a high concentration of CO2. Klier et al. reported that the methanol productivity reached a maximum when the ratio of CO2/CO decreased to 1/14 [4], which implied that the presence of CO2 causes an unfavorable effect on methanol productivity. Industrial methanol synthesis process is mostly run with a synthesis gas that contains approximately 5% CO2 [28]. As a method of CO2 utilization, methanol synthesis from CO2 has been tried in many studies, but methanol productivity has been low, and the process was less energy-efficient than the synthesis using CO. A large quantity of CO2 is always included in commercially produced synthesis gases. However, we considered that the removal of CO2 should not be regarded as indispensable because it requires high costs and is undesirable in terms of CO2 utilization. Therefore, the reaction tests were carried out with a CO/CO2/H2 reactant gas, which contained a relatively high concentration of CO2 (9.5%). 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Ce1−x Zr x O2 support The preparation method of Ce1−x Zr x O2 (x =0, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 1) supports was based on the previous literature report [29]. The aqueous solutions (0.1M) of cerium chloride heptahydrate (Aldrich, 99.9%) and zirconyl chloride octahydrate (Sigma–Aldrich, 98%) were mixed together with a 0.1M aqueous solution of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, Sigma, >99%). Subsequently, ammonium hydroxide (28wt.% NH4OH, Sigma–Aldrich) was added to the mixture solutions with vigorous stirring at room temperature until the pH of the solution reached pH 11.5. As the pH approached to 11.5, the color of the solution changed from purple to yellow. The stirring continued for 2h and then the slurry was aged at 363K for 5 days without stirring. Next, the solution was cooled to room temperature and the yellow precipitate was filtered and washed several times with ethanol and de-ionized water to remove the free CTAB. The filtered precipitate was dried at 333K for 16h and calcined in air at 673K (ramp rate: 1K/min) for 4h. 2.2 Impregnation of Cu on Ce1−x Zr x O2 support The Cu-loaded catalysts (y wt.% Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2, y =8, 12, 16, 20, 24) were prepared by deposition–precipitation method. Copper nitrate trihydrate (Aldrich, >99%) was dissolved in de-ionized water and the Ce1−x Zr x O2 support was added and mixed with vigorous stirring at room temperature. For 1g of Ce1−x Zr x O2 support, 120mL of copper nitrate solution was applied [30]. An aqueous solution (0.25M) of sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, Sigma–Aldrich, >99%) was slowly added to the mixture until the pH reached 7.5. After 2h of aging, the precipitates were filtered and washed several times with de-ionized water to remove any remaining sodium ions. Drying and calcination processes were same as stated for the preparation of Ce1−x Zr x O2 support. 2.3 Characterization Residue of the free surfactant in the sample after calcination was identified by using FT-IR (Spectrum GX, Perkin Elmer) operating in transmission mode at a resolution of 1cm−1. The sample powders were diluted with KBr and then immobilized. All spectra were recorded with 32 scans at room temperature. The specific surface areas and pore volumes of the calcined supports were measured from N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms (at 77K) obtained by a BET instrument (ASAP 2010, Micrometrics). Before each analysis, the sample was degassed at 473K for at least 4h. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were obtained with an ATX-G X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku) using Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation (λ =1.5418Å) at 40kV and 200mA. The range of 2θ was 20–80° with a step size of 0.02° and the scan speed was 2°min−1. The exposed copper surface area was determined by the N2O pulse titration method [31]. The calcined sample (20mg) was pre-reduced with 5% H2/He (S.T.P. 50mL/min) at 573K for 30min and then flushed with pure He gas until the temperature cooled down to 363K. A pulse (0.1mL) of 5% N2O/He gas was injected repetitively into sample tube until no more N2 was detected by TCD. The injected N2O gas was reduced into N2 on the copper surface according to the following reaction (1). (1) N2O+2Cu→N2 +Cu2O The copper surface area was calculated based on the assumption that the stoichiometry of N2O titration to Cu was 2 and the quantity of Cu atoms in the specific area was 1.46×1019 Cuatom/m2 [28]. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was performed by using M-BELCAT (BEL Japan Inc.) in the range of 323–773K. Each sample was pretreated at 573K with flowing pure He gas (50mL/min) for 30min. The TCD signal was recorded with the ramp rate of 2K/min under 40mL/min of 5% H2/N2 flow. The surface acidity of the catalysts was measured by the NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) method. A sample (0.05g) was initially reduced at 573K under 5% H2/He flow (40mL/min). It was cooled down to 373K and NH3 was adsorbed for 30min with flowing 5% NH3/He gas at 30mL/min. The excess NH3 was removed at 373K with He flow (30mL/min) for another 2h. The NH3 desorption profile was recorded under He flow (30mL/min. while heating the sample from 373 to 823K at a heating rate of 5K/min. The presence of oxygen vacancies and the microstructures of Ce1−x Zr x O2 were studied using Raman spectra, which were collected on a FT-Raman Spectrometer (FRA 106/S, Bruker) operating at 514.5nm with an Ar+ laser beam. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained with an ESCA2000 (VG Microtech) that was operated at 1.3×10−12 atm. The X-ray source was Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV) and all of the core-level binding energies were calibrated with C 1s binding energy referenced at 284.6eV. 2.4 Activity test Each prepared catalyst (0.3g) was tested in a fixed-bed stainless steel reactor (I.D., 7.75mm) under 30bar of flowing feed gas (H2:CO:CO2:N2 =66.5:19:9.5:5) at a total flow rate of 24mL/min, which corresponded to w/f of 0.75gcat s/mL. Before every activity test, the catalyst bed was pre-reduced for 3h with 60mL/min of 10% H2/He at 575K, 1atm. The reaction pressure (30bar) was controlled with a backpressure regulator (Tescom). The product flow line was constantly heated to 413K to prevent condensation of the produced methanol. The quantitative analysis of the products were performed using an on-line gas chromatography that was equipped with a Carboxene 1000 (packed, 60/80 mesh, 15ft×1/8in.) and HP-PLOT Q (capillary, 40.0μm, 0.53mm×30m) columns, which were used for separating inorganic (CO, CO2, N2) and organic (C1–C4, CH3OH, CH3OCH3) gas species, respectively. Both TCD and FID were used as detectors. Conversion of CO x (CO, CO2) and (C 1-based) selectivity of methanol were calculated by using the following equations. (2) X CO x = C CO x ( in ) × v ( in ) − C CO x ( out ) × v ( out ) C CO x ( in ) × v ( in ) (3) S methanol = C methanol Σ C product × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts The amount of surfactant remaining in the sample before and after calcination was verified by FT-IR (Fig. 1 ) and elemental analysis (Table 1 ). Before calcination, the FT-IR peaks at 2850–2950, 1478 and 1430cm−1 were observed, which were the characteristic peaks of the CTAB surfactant. The peaks at 2850–2950cm−1 represent the symmetric and asymmetric CH stretching vibrations of the alkyl chain of the CTAB molecules, and the peaks at 1482cm−1 and 1430cm−1 denote the CH scissoring vibration of the CH3-N+ moiety [32]. The peaks disappeared after calcination. The elemental analysis of the calcined sample resulted in very low concentrations of N and C, which suggested that the surfactant was almost totally removed by calcination. The BET properties of the Ce1−x Zr x O2 support are summarized in Table 2 . Compared to the analogous samples that were prepared by other methods, the prepared samples were characterized by relatively high surface area and pore volume. When cerium and zirconium chloride precursors were co-precipitated, it was known that the hydrous mixed metal oxides (Ce1−x Zr x -OH) were formed first. At high pH (>11, 11.5 in our case), cation exchange was promoted between the hydroxyl group of the oxide and the cations of the surfactant (CTAB), which resulted in the gel-type structure where the surfactant chains acted like a scaffold, which prevented the collapse of the porous network during drying and calcination [33]. It is also known that sufficient aging time (5 days, in our case) is effective for the stabilization of the precursor–surfactant complex, which was used to result in the high-surface area and porous texture of the final precipitate [29]. As presented in Table 2, the total pore volume was similar among all of the Ce1−x Zr x O2 (except x =1, ZrO2); therefore, the surface area of the samples increased with a decrease in the average pore size. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm profiles of Ce1−x Zr x O2 supports are presented in Fig. 2 . For all of the calcined samples, the adsorption isotherms were type IV (Fig. 2A). The hysteresis loops indicated that the samples have a typical mesoporous structure. As the Zr content (i.e., x) increased in the Ce1−x Zr x O2 samples of x =0.3, 0.5, 0.7, the pore size distribution became narrower with a decrease in the average pore size (Fig. 2B). Fig. 3 displays the XRD patterns of the 8wt.% Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 catalysts. The catalysts generally exhibited cubic (fluorite) structure except for ZrO2 which was amorphous in its crystallinity. As the Zr content (x) increased, the Braggs peaks were shifted to higher angles, which implied that the lattice size became smaller. It was because the Ce4+ (0.97Å) ions were substituted with Zr4+, which is a smaller ion (0.84Å). The lattice parameters of the catalysts are shown in Table 3 . When x increased from 0 to 0.5, the magnitudes of parameters (a, c) decreased, while maintaining the magnitude ratio (c/a) at 1. As will be shown in the Raman spectra later, there was no tetragonal phase detected for these catalysts, which indicated that the catalysts did not deviate much from the cubic structure. At x =0.7 (Cu/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2), a discrepancy in the parameter ratio (c/a) was observed. However, we could not confirm that the structure transformed from cubic toward tetragonal in this catalyst because the tetragonal phase was not detected in the Raman spectrum of the catalyst (again, it will be presented later.) Therefore, it was proposed that the structure of Cu/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 was a pseudo-cubic phase, which was slightly distorted in the lattice parameters [34–36]. In the case of ZrO2 (x =1), it seemed that the tetragonal structure was not fully developed. This result was also observed by Hudson et al., who claimed that the tetragonal phase of ZrO2 was not formed when it was prepared through a similar method [33]. It was expected that the low calcination temperature (674K) was the main reason for the absence of crystallinity in our ZrO2 sample. According to previous studies [26,37], the incorporation of Zr into the CeO2 lattice caused the displacement of the cubic lattice, and this structural fluctuation might enhance the generation of oxygen vacancies across the lattices. The presence of oxygen vacancies in Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 catalysts was confirmed by Raman and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Fig. 4 presents the Raman spectra of the Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 catalysts. All of the catalysts except for Cu/ZrO2 exhibited strong bands at 461cm−1. The spectra of Cu/ZrO2 did not exhibit the conventional, six Raman-active bands of ZrO2, which may be because the tetragonal structure of ZrO2 was not fully developed. As the Zr content (x) in Ce1−x Zr x O2 was increased, the intensity of the band at 461cm−1 decreased because the band represents the characteristic, F2g Raman active mode of the fluorite cubic structure. In addition to the band at 461cm−1, another band appeared at 600cm−1 for the catalysts where x =0.3 and 0.5. This weak band is associated with the oxygen vacancies in the CeO2 lattice [20,38,39]. From this, the presence of the oxygen vacancies were verified in the Cu/Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 (x =0.3) and Cu/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 (x =0.5) catalysts. In general, the tetragonal Raman-active peaks were not detected over the catalysts. Therefore, we could conclude that all of the catalysts except for x =1 (Cu/ZrO2) consisted of a pseudo-cubic, crystalline phase. The XPS results of Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 are provided in Table 4 and Fig. 5 . In Table 4, the surface Ce/Zr ratio was almost same as the bulk Ce/Zr ratio, which demonstrated that cerium and zirconium were distributed homogeneously over a catalyst. The amount of oxygen vacancies in Ce1−x Zr x O2 depended on the concentration of Ce3+, which was estimated by using Ce 3d spectra. In Fig. 5A, each Ce 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 spectrum was deconvoluted into 5 component peaks, which were grouped as ‘v’ (v 0, v, v′, v″, v‴) and ‘u’ (u 0, u, u′, u″, u‴), respectively [40]. Each peak represents a spin-orbit coupling, which leads to a unique hybridization state between the Ce 4f and O 2p bands [40]: to be specific, the (1) v‴+ u‴ corresponded to the photoemission from the Ce(IV)O2 (Ce4f 0O2p6) state; the (2) v + u and v″+ u″ were from the Ce(IV)O2 (Ce4f 2O2p4) and (Ce4f 1O2p5) state, respectively; the (3) v 0 + u 0 and v′+ u′ were from the Ce2(III)O3 (Ce4f 2O2p4) and (Ce4f 1O2p5) state [40,41]. Therefore, the v′ (v 0) and u′ (u 0) peaks were used for determining the concentration of the Ce3+. Běche et al. and Pfau et al. calculated the concentration of Ce3+ by using the following Eq. (4) [42,43]. (4) Concentration of Ce 3 + = u 0 + u ′ + v o + v ′ Σ u i + v i The Ce3+ concentration in each catalyst is presented in Table 4. The order of catalysts relative to Ce3+ concentration was Cu/Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 (37.9%)>Cu/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 (30.8%)>Cu/CeO2 (27.8%)>Cu/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 (21.4%). In Fig. 5B, the O 1s peak was deconvoluted into three peaks. According to Ilieva et al., the O 1s peaks at 529.6, 531.5 and 533.4eV, were attributed to the lattice oxygen, chemisorbed surface oxygen species (ex. hydroxyl group) and oxygen adsorbed on Ce3+ defects, respectively [44]. The area percentage for each O 1s peak is listed in Table 4 , where we could find the order of catalysts with respect to area % of −533eV O 1s peak was Cu/Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 (12.6%)>Cu/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 (10.7%)>Cu/CeO2 (6.6%)>Cu/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 (5.1%), which was same order as was observed for the Ce3+ concentration. Therefore, it was concluded that the Cu/Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 contained the highest concentration of oxygen vacancies among the prepared catalysts. The TPR data of the calcined Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 is presented in Fig. 6 and the temperature window was divided based on the literatures [25,45]. The low temperature TPR signal (410–420K, region α) represents the reduction of highly dispersed CuO or Cu2+ ions that strongly interacted with the supports. The moderate temperature signal (420–450K, region β) corresponds to the reduction of the larger CuO particles that weakly interacted with the supports. It was reported that the dispersed CuO across the Ce/Zr oxide was lower in reduction temperature than the pure CuO, which was because the Ce/Zr oxide enhanced the reduction of CuO. The highest temperature signal (>450K, γ region) was attributed to the reduction of Cu2+ ions that were incorporated into the mixed oxide lattices [45,46] or the reduction of CuO particles that were the weakest in their degree of interaction with Ce1−x Zr x O2 [47,48]. The reduction of perfectly free, bulk CuO was reported to maximized above 573K [49]. Fig. 6 demonstrates that the TPR signal shifted to a higher temperature as the amount of Zr (x) increased in the Ce1−x Zr x O2, which implies that the ceria phase dispersed the CuO, but its effect was diminished with an increase in Zr content. As x increased, especially when pure zirconia was applied, the γ signal became strong. The prepared catalysts contained almost equal amounts (7.4–7.6wt.%) of Cu species (Table 3), but the exposed Cu surface area (Table 5) was significantly reduced from 8.1m2 Cu/gcat (Cu/CeO2) to 0.6m2 Cu/gcat (Cu/ZrO2) as Zr amount (x) was increased in Ce1−x Zr x O2. However, the appearance of the γ-region TPR signal and the decrease of exposed Cu surface area could not be attributed wholly to the formation of larger CuO particles. As presented in Table 5, the H2 consumption that was measured during TPR runs deviated from the theoretical values (based on the complete reduction of the loaded CuO). The ratio of the measured value over the theoretical one could be over 100% because ceria could be partly reduced during the TPR runs in the presence of active metal (Cu, Rh, Pd) [50,51]. Cu/CeO2 (105%) and Cu/Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 (108%) could be examples of these cases. When considering the possibility of ceria reduction, the ‘actual’ measured/theoretical H2 consumption ratios for CuO reduction would be smaller than the ratios listed in Table 5. For the catalysts where x ≥0.5, the measured/theoretical ratio was below 100% and decreased with the increase of x, falling from 98% (x =0.5, Cu/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2) to 59% (x =1, Cu/ZrO2). The increase of CuO particle size at x ≥0.5 could not explain this result (i.e., the decrease of the ratio toward 59%). It was expected that a portion of the Cu oxide would be incorporated into the lattice of Ce1−x Zr x O2, and become stabilized against reduction [46]. NH3-TPD data of Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 are presented in Fig. 7 and Table 5, which reveal that the total surface acidity of the Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 increased when the amount of Zr increased (x). These results were similar to the results of Gutiérrez-Ortiz et al., who had claimed that increasing the Zr amount leads to an increase in the surface acidity of Ce1−x Zr x O2 (unsupported) [26]. They also claimed that the acid sites on the Ce1−x Zr x O2 were dominantly Lewis acidic. 3.2 Methanol synthesis activity The yield and selectivity of methanol for Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 catalysts are presented in Fig. 8 . Cu/CeO2 (i.e., x =0) demonstrated a continuous increase in the methanol yield over the entire temperature range, while the other catalysts reached their maximum yields between 530 and 555K, which turned to decrease as the temperature increased higher (Fig. 8A). This result implied that the rate of methanol dehydration into dimethyl ether (DME) was substantial over the Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 catalysts except Cu/CeO2. (5) 2CH3OH→CH3OCH3 +H2O As shown in Fig. 8B, the methanol selectivity monotonically decreased with temperature, while the DME selectivity increased almost exactly in proportion to the decrease in methanol selectivity. (In all cases, the sum of methanol and DME selectivity was almost 100%.) As x increased in the Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 catalysts, the methanol dehydration (i.e., DME formation) became more prominent. The methanol dehydration is usually catalyzed by the acid sites on a catalyst. The NH3-TPD data (Fig. 7) revealed that the introduction of Zr increased the surface acidity of catalyst, which would promote the methanol dehydration to form DME. However, as shown in Fig. 8A, the Zr-incorporated catalysts, such as Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 (x =0.3. 0.5, 0.7), were higher than Cu/CeO2 in methanol yield only if the temperature was below 533K. These results indicated that the surface acidity was not as decisive a factor for methanol yield as it was for selectivity. Fig. 9 presents the CO x conversion and methanol yield at 533K, which are correlated with Cu surface area and Ce3+ concentration of the Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 catalysts. The Cu surface area is a key factor for explaining the activity of CO hydrogenation because the Cu provides the active sites for a variety of elemental steps in the mechanism, especially for the dissociation of hydrogen molecules [52–54]. The Ce3+ concentration was also expected to be important because it directly relates to the amount of oxygen vacancies that provide the binding sites for CO and CO2 [14,18]. In Fig. 9, the CO x conversion was strictly proportional to the concentration of Ce3+ (i.e., amount of oxygen vacancy) in the catalyst. The discrepancy between CO x conversion and methanol yield could be attributed to DME yield which had been related to the surface acidity of a catalyst in the previous discussion. Although it was influenced by the surface acidity, the methanol yield was generally dependent on the surface area of Cu and the concentration of Ce3+. The best methanol yield was achieved with Cu/Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 (i.e., x =0.3), which ranked high among the catalysts in terms of Cu surface area and Ce3+ concentration. The influence of the Cu surface area is clearly confirmed in Fig. 10 , which presents the change of methanol yield over Cu/Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 when the Cu loading increased from 8 to 24wt.%. Because the same support material (Ce0.7Zr0.3O2) was used, we could fix the influences of oxygen vacancy and surface acidity at constant level and directly reveal the influence of the Cu surface area on the activity. As observed in Fig. 10, the Cu surface area increased with the rise of loading up to 20wt.%, but turned to decrease with further increases in the Cu loading. It was found that the methanol yield followed the trend of Cu surface area, which revealed that the exposed Cu surface area determined the methanol yield when the oxygen vacancy and surface acidity remained constant. Consequently, it cannot be denied that Cu surface area was crucial factor for methanol synthesis, but the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the catalysts, as well as the Cu surface area, were also important. However, when comparing Cu/CeO2 with Cu/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 (i.e., x =0.7) in Fig. 9, Cu/CeO2 demonstrated inferior CO x conversion and methanol yield, even though it was higher both in Cu surface area and Ce3+ concentration (oxygen vacancy concentration). (Moreover, it should be considered that Cu/CeO2 had the lowest surface acidity and was almost inactive for dehydration of methanol into DME.) This effect was caused by the difference in the mobility of the CO x species that were adsorbed on the vacancy site. It is well known that the mobility of oxygen is greatly enhanced when Zr is incorporated into the CeO2 lattices [55,56]. Therefore, the mobility of the CO x adsorbed on the oxygen vacancy sites would be higher in Ce-Zr mixed oxides than in CeO2, which would influence the overall rate of hydrogenation. Considering the influence of CO x mobility on activity, it was expected that the major route of CO x hydrogenation over Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 (especially x =0.3, 0.5 where concentration of oxygen vacancy was high) consisted of the following elementary steps: (1) H2 was chemisorbed onto the Cu site; (2) CO x was adsorbed on the oxygen vacancy of the Ce1−x Zr x O2 support; (2) CO x migrated to the adjacent H-Cu site; (3) CO x was reduced into methanol by that hydrogen that was chemisorbed on the Cu; (4) A portion of the produced methanol was dehydrated to form DME over the acidic surface sites of the Ce1−x Zr x O2 support. 4 Conclusions In this study, we prepared high surface area Ce1−x Zr x O2 supports by using a surfactant-assisted co-precipitation method, and copper was loaded onto the support as an active species for the synthesis of methanol from CO/CO2/H2 gas. Introduction of Zr into the CeO2 lattice decreased the lattice parameter of the fluorite cubic structure. The prepared Ce1−x Zr x O2 (x =0.3, 0.5) exhibited a defective, pseudo-cubic structure where the increase in oxygen vacancy was detected by Raman and XPS (Ce 3d and O 1s) analysis. The amount of oxygen vacancy was the highest when x =0.3 (Ce0.7Zr0.3O2). The exposed surface area of Cu in the Cu-loaded Ce1−x Zr x O2 catalyst (8wt.% Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2) decreased with increases in the amount of Zr (x). From the H2 consumption data in TPR study, it was expected that a portion of the copper oxide was incorporated into the lattice of the Ce1−x Zr x O2, especially when x ≥0.5. During the activity test, the dehydration of methanol into DME became noticeable with the zirconium-rich catalysts, which was governed by the surface acidity of the catalysts, but the yield of methanol was generally dependent upon the exposed surface area of Cu and the amount of oxygen vacancy in Ce1−x Zr x O2 support. The best activity was obtained with Cu/Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 (i.e., x =0.3). However, it was expected that the mobility of the species adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies was another factor that influenced the activity of the catalysts, which was revealed through comparison between the Cu/CeO2 and the Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2. In consequence, it was expected that when Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 (especially x =0.3 and 0.5) was used as a catalyst, CO and CO2 were captured on the oxygen vacancies and migrated to the adjacent H-Cu site to be reduced into methanol. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we investigated the catalysis of Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 for the synthesis of methanol from CO/CO2/H2 gas. The Ce1−x Zr x O2 was synthesized by a surfactant (CTAB)-assisted co-precipitation method to yield high surface area supports, and Cu was deposited on the supports by a deposition–precipitation method to promote high Cu dispersion. The incorporation of Zr into the CeO2 lattice transformed the structure into a defective, pseudo-cubic one and the amount of incorporated Zr (x) determined the concentration of oxygen vacancy in the lattice. It was proposed that the oxygen vacancy in Ce1−x Zr x O2 played an important role in the catalysis by determining concentration and mobility of the adsorbed CO x on the catalyst. The activity was also influenced by the exposed surface area of Cu and surface acidity of the catalyst, both of which were closely related to the amount of Zr in the support. To reveal the influences of the catalyst properties on methanol production, various characterization techniques were used, such as XPS, Raman spectroscopy, XRD, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, BET and N2O titration methods.
coredata.dc:title: The synthesis of methanol from CO/CO2/H2 gas over Cu/Ce1−x Zr x O2 catalysts
